title: Incredible illuminations will be projected onto St Paul's Cathedral to remember London's war dead
text:
Iconic St Paul's Cathedral will be transformed over the next few days by a spectacular light display which will pay tribute to the people who fought to save the landmark during the Second World War.

The illuminations, from creative company Double Take Projections, will be projected onto the cathedral over the next four evenings as part of the Where Light Falls festival.

Preview images give a glimpse of what's in store for spectators, including powerful poetry, visuals and photography used to tell the story of St Paul's Watch, the volunteers who risked their lives protecting it during the Blitz.

As bombs rained down on London, St Paul’s Watch volunteers patrolled the monument ready to leap into action and put out flames. Their courage is credited with the cathedral surviving to this day.

The breathtaking tribute ties into the 80th anniversary commemorations of the Blitz this year.

St Paul’s famously survived the Blitz, despite being struck by bombs on October 10 1940 and April 17 1941.

It became a symbol of British courage during the Second World War, after Herbert Mason photographed the cathedral during the Second Great Fire of London on December 29 1940.

The image shows St Paul’s iconic dome emerging from the billows of smoke covering the streets of the capital. It is one of the most iconic photos taken of the devastation the Second World War wrought on home soil.

The projections include archive images of King George VI, animation and new poetry from London-based poet Keith Jarrett. Jarrett held workshops with local schoolchildren, older writers, refugees and migrants who have experienced conflict and included their thoughts in his work.

Jarrett said: ‘I have drawn…inspiration from the humour, the personal relationships, and the perseverance through adversity expressed through the records I have encountered.’

St Paul’s is one of two landmarks being commemorated in this way, with Coventry Cathedral also being lit up for three days next month to tell the city’s story.

Coventry Cathedral was destroyed in the Second World War, after an air raid on the October 14 1940.

A new Cathedral was built, which preserved the remains of the old Cathedral and aimed to serve as a reminder of the waste of war.

Poet Jane Commane, whose words will be brought to life during the display said part of her poem includes responses from people to the question ‘what does Coventry Cathedral mean to you?’
description: St Paul's Cathedral will be transformed by a spectacular light display which pays tribute to the people who fought to save it during the Second World War.
